Custody of a Minor, 430 Mass. 10 (1999).raw_text: Custody of a Minor, 430 Mass. 10 (1999) (best-interests standard discussion);
Custody of a Minor, 430 Mass. 10 (1999).proposition: Relevant Massachusetts precedent directs the Court to prioritize the best interests of the child, to consider evidence of parental fitness, and to impose conditions or supervision when required to protect the child’s safety.
Custody of a Minor, 430 Mass. 10 (1999).support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal stalking case, not a custody or child-welfare case, and it never discusses the ‘best interests of the child’ standard, parental fitness, or the imposition of conditions/supervision in a custody or visitation context. Its references to a divorce judgment and a Probate and Family Court order relate only to whether violation of that order can satisfy an element of the stalking statute. It therefore does not provide authority for the claimed child-custody best-interests proposition.
Custody of a Minor, 430 Mass. 10 (1999).relevant_excerpt: "The defendant was in violation of an order that was part of the divorce judgment. As discussed in a recent case, see Champagne v. Champagne, 429 Mass. 324, 326 (1999), this order was entered pursuant to the Probate and Family Court’s authority under G. L. c. 208, § 18, which provides, in part, that ‘the [Probate and Family Court] may make such further order as it deems necessary to protect either party or their children, to preserve the peace or to carry out the purposes of this section relative to restraint on personal liberty.’"

Custody of a Minor, 407 Mass. 174 (1990).case_name: DiMartino v. Quality Industrial Propane, Inc.
Custody of a Minor, 407 Mass. 174 (1990).support_reasoning: The excerpted opinion is a workers’ compensation/third‑party settlement case about an insurer’s rights under G.L. c. 152, § 15, not a child custody or modification case. It does not discuss best interests of the child, parental fitness, or imposing conditions/supervision to protect a child’s safety. The citation described in the prompt (Custody of a Minor, 407 Mass. 174 (1990)) is not the same as the case text provided, so this text does not support the stated child‑custody proposition.
Custody of a Minor, 407 Mass. 174 (1990).relevant_excerpt: “As we see it, the principal question on appeal is whether INA was entitled to the judge’s review of the fairness of the settlement agreement beyond the judge’s satisfying himself that the agreement provided (as it clearly did) that INA would be reimbursed in full for the payments it had made to DiMartino, thus discharging the lien provided by c. 152, § 15. Our answer to that question is ‘no,’ for the reasons we discuss below.”

J.L. v. M.L., 444 Mass. 560 (2005) (pare.raw_text: J.L. v. M.L., 444 Mass. 560 (2005) (parental fitness and best interests);
J.L. v. M.L., 444 Mass. 560 (2005) (pare.proposition: Relevant Massachusetts precedent directs the Court to prioritize the best interests of the child, to consider evidence of parental fitness, and to impose conditions or supervision when required to protect the child’s safety.
J.L. v. M.L., 444 Mass. 560 (2005) (pare.support_reasoning: The quoted opinion is a Massachusetts criminal case about exclusion of third‑party culprit evidence and the defendant’s right to present a defense. It does not concern parental fitness, custody, or best interests of the child, nor does it discuss imposing conditions or supervision to protect a child’s safety. Citing this case for a proposition about family-law best-interests analysis and parental fitness is inaccurate and out of context.
J.L. v. M.L., 444 Mass. 560 (2005) (pare.relevant_excerpt: “The defendant contends that the judge’s ruling, preventing him from displaying Pedro to the jury, violated his ‘constitutional right to present evidence that another may have committed the crime.’… Here, however, the defendant sought to introduce evidence that was highly probative… On this record, we see no valid reason for the judge to have precluded the defendant from presenting Pedro to the jury… and it was therefore an abuse of discretion to have excluded this highly relevant exculpatory evidence.”
